original_data.question: A 48-year-old Caucasian female presents to her primary care physician for evaluation of progressive weakness and shortness of breath. She has had progressive shortness of breath over the last year with an intermittent non-productive cough. In addition, she complains of difficulty raising her arms to brush her hair. Her temperature is 99.6°F (37.6°C), pulse is 80/min, blood pressure is 130/85 mmHg, respirations are 18/min, and oxygen saturation is 95% on room air. Neurologic exam shows 4/5 strength in the deltoid muscles bilaterally. Diffuse dry crackles are heard on lung auscultation. A faint erythematous rash is noted on the malar cheeks, periorbital areas, lateral proximal thighs, and the elbows. Which of the following tests is most likely to confirm the diagnosis?

model_response:
The patient has dermatomyositis, which is one of the inflammatory myopathies. The typical rash described in the question stem is periorbital, but can also be found on the trunk and extremities. The rash is often photosensitive and can be pruritic. The typical age group is older adults, but it can occur in children. The other findings in the question stem are consistent with interstitial lung disease. The diagnostic test of choice is a muscle biopsy. The biopsy will show perivascular mononuclear cell infiltrates with associated degeneration and regeneration of muscle fibers. The other tests listed in the question stem are not specific for dermatomyositis. A CT scan may be helpful in evaluating the extent of lung disease, but would not confirm the diagnosis. A serum ANA titer is elevated in many autoimmune diseases and would not specifically confirm the diagnosis. A skin biopsy may be helpful in evaluating the extent of the rash, but would not confirm the diagnosis.

Answer: OPTION A IS CORRECT.</s><s>

question_entities.definition: A group distinguished by classification according to physical features. This group, also called Europoid, centers around the Mediterranean Sea but includes other parts of Europe. (from Winick: Dictionary of Anthropology, 1972; American Heritage Dictionary, 2d College ed)
Human females as cultural, psychological, sociological, political, and economic entities.
Providers of initial care for patients. These PHYSICIANS refer patients when appropriate for secondary or specialist care.
Systematic, objective appraisal of the significance, effectiveness, and impact of activities or condition according to specified objectives and criteria.
Advancing in extent or severity.
Clinical sign or symptom manifested as debility, or lack or loss of strength and energy.
Height greater than two standard deviations below the mean of the appropriate reference population for the age and sex of the individual.
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.
Advancing in extent or severity.
Height greater than two standard deviations below the mean of the appropriate reference population for the age and sex of the individual.
The air that is inhaled and exhaled during respiration.
A period of time that it takes for Earth to make a complete revolution around the sun, approximately 365 days; a specific one year period.
Periodically stopping and starting.
A cough that is not accompanied by expectorated secretions.
A symptom or problem for which a patient seeks medical attention.
Something not easily done, accomplished, comprehended, or solved.
Device consisting of hairs or bristles set into a handle or holder, especially one that conducts current between the rotating and stationary parts of a generator or motor.

A filament-like structure consisting of a shaft which projects to the surface of the SKIN from a root which is softer than the shaft and lodges in the cavity of a HAIR FOLLICLE. It is found on most surfaces of the body.
The measure of the level of heat of a human or animal.
The rhythmical expansion and contraction of an ARTERY produced by waves of pressure caused by the ejection of BLOOD from the left ventricle of the HEART as it contracts.
PRESSURE of the BLOOD on the ARTERIES and other BLOOD VESSELS.
A non-SI unit of pressure equal to 133,332 Pa or 1.316E10-3 standard atmosphere. Use of this unit is generally deprecated by ISO and IUPAC.

The act of breathing with the LUNGS, consisting of INHALATION, or the taking into the lungs of the ambient air, and of EXHALATION, or the expelling of the modified air which contains more CARBON DIOXIDE than the air taken in (Blakiston's Gould Medical Dictionary, 4th ed.). This does not include tissue respiration (= OXYGEN CONSUMPTION) or cell respiration (= CELL RESPIRATION).
Unmodified air as existing in the immediate surroundings.
Pertaining to nerves or the nervous system.
Degree of intensity or force in regard to a physical activity.
Thick triangular muscle in the SHOULDER whose function is to abduct, flex, and extend the arm. It is a common site of INTRAMUSCULAR INJECTIONS.
Affecting both sides of the body or a matched pair of organs.
A condition in which a person partially loses the ability to hear sounds in one or both ears.
Act of listening for sounds within the body.

A transient loss of consciousness and postural tone caused by diminished blood flow to the brain (i.e., BRAIN ISCHEMIA). Presyncope refers to the sensation of lightheadedness and loss of strength that precedes a syncopal event or accompanies an incomplete syncope. (From Adams et al., Principles of Neurology, 6th ed, pp367-9)
Either of a pair of bones that form the prominent part of the CHEEK and contribute to the ORBIT on each side of the SKULL.
The part of the face that is below the eye and to the side of the nose and mouth.
The area surrounding the eye.
An unpleasant sensation characterized by physical discomfort (such as pricking, throbbing, or aching) localized to the elbow. [UToronto:chum]
Any procedure that involves testing or manipulating a sample of blood, urine, or other body substance in a laboratory setting.

The determination of the nature of a disease or condition, or the distinguishing of one disease or condition from another. Assessment may be made through physical examination, laboratory tests, or the likes. Computerized programs may be used to enhance the decision-making process.
